docs.lead_paragraph: I still briefly flounder when I meet someone — at the dog run, at the laundry or in line at the bodega — and as the conversation turns to work and I say I have a restaurant, they ask: What kind of restaurant is it?

headline.main: A Shrimp Roll Inspired by Ikea
headline.print_headline: A Shrimp Roll Inspired by Ikea

docs.abstract: Can you just sell something that someone lends to you, so long as they forgot that they lent it to you?
docs.snippet: Can you just sell something that someone lends to you, so long as they forgot that they lent it to you?
docs.lead_paragraph: Matt writes: Years ago, my sister, Brooke, borrowed a camera lens of mine. I forgot about it until I needed it a year later. That’s when she told me she had sold it to our friend, Evan. I asked her to replace it, and she said that because we both forgot about it, I should just replace it myself. It cost me $115. Having you settle a claim that small feels petty. I want a genuine apology from her.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Proper Borrowing Etiquette
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: At least 143 pro-government forces and 51 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
docs.snippet: At least 143 pro-government forces and 51 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
docs.lead_paragraph: At least 143 pro-government forces and 52 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during another bloody week of fighting amid ongoing peace talks in Doha. The deadliest attack took place in Kunduz Province, where the Taliban attacked two military bases and several security outposts in Imam Sahib District, capturing one base and three security outposts in seven hours of fighting. At least 20 members of the security forces were killed, 15 were wounded and another 10 were taken prisoner. On Sunday, a Taliban car bomb killed 12 people in Ghazni City. Nearly 200 people were also wounded in the explosion, including more than 100 children.

docs.abstract: Wave an arm, yell for help — but don’t freak out — and tread water.
docs.snippet: Wave an arm, yell for help — but don’t freak out — and tread water.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Panic is what drowns people,” Rob Brander says. He has been dropping things into rip currents for decades — brightly colored dyes, GPS-enabled drifters, graduate students and volunteer swimmers with GPS units strapped to their heads, even his own body. “If you end up in a rip current, don’t freak out,” says Brander, a coastal geomorphologist and professor at the University of New South Wales, in Sydney. The current will not pull you under. In fact, often the water moves you away from shore only to circle you back to the shallows.

headline.main: How to Escape a Rip Current
headline.print_headline: How to Escape a Rip Current

docs.abstract: Sperm banks never imagined a world where donors could be tracked down by DNA. But now children can find their biological fathers — and each other.
docs.snippet: Sperm banks never imagined a world where donors could be tracked down by DNA. But now children can find their biological fathers — and each other.
docs.lead_paragraph: To be the biological child of an anonymous sperm donor today is to live in a state of perpetual anticipation. Having never imagined a world in which donors could be tracked down by DNA, in their early years sperm banks did not limit the number of families to whom one donor’s sperm would be sold — means that many of the children conceived have half-siblings in the dozens. There are hundreds of biological half-sibling groups that number more than 20, according to the Donor Sibling Registry, where siblings can find one another, using their donor number. Groups larger than 100, the registry reports, are far from rare.

headline.main: Sperm Donors Can’t Stay Secret Anymore. Here’s What That Means.
headline.print_headline: Epilogue: A Dark Secret No More

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether or not to butt out.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether or not to butt out.
docs.lead_paragraph: My family is elderly, and my aunt — who is in her late 70s — was recently diagnosed with Alzheimer’s. If someone does not go with her to appointments, she often forgets what was discussed, including medication, follow-up appointments or even why surgery is scheduled. We know that this will get worse with time.

headline.main: My Aunt Has Alzheimer’s and Her Husband Doesn’t Seem to Care
headline.print_headline: My Aunt Has Alzheimer’s And Her Husband Doesn’t Seem to Care. Should We Butt Out?

docs.abstract: Social skills needed. Watch out for men in their 20s, especially after midnight. Approach them and say hello.
docs.snippet: Social skills needed. Watch out for men in their 20s, especially after midnight. Approach them and say hello.
docs.lead_paragraph: “You don’t need to be the biggest guy in the room,” says Robert C. Smith, a San Diego-based nightclub consultant who has trained more than 10,000 bouncers nationwide. In fact, you don’t need to be a guy at all. You do need social skills: the ability to talk to people, spot potential problems, de-escalate tensions, stay calm. “It’s about how do you avoid using force,” Smith says.

docs.abstract: You used to need a secret recording to learn what politicians said in private. Now we can get the same illicit thrill from their public statements.
docs.snippet: You used to need a secret recording to learn what politicians said in private. Now we can get the same illicit thrill from their public statements.
docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden is suited, floating in a black void of stage, sitting cross-legged across from a glamorous woman in a striking red jacket, speaking to an invisible crowd. “The younger generation now tells me how tough things are,” he says. “Give me a break. No, no, I have no empathy for it. Give me a break. Because here’s the deal, guys: We decided we were going to change the world. And we did.” He delivers the line in high avuncular style, stating an opinion with the tone and cadence of a meaningful story. The crowd, whoever they are, laughs. They’re not the “guys” being told what the “deal” is. Those people are somewhere else.

headline.main: Biden’s Gaffes, and Why We Hate Politicians Talking About Us Behind Our Backs
